evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the consistent evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim report indicating its critical role in the incident.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown includes failures in signaling and alerting among crew and operators
Lack of warning signals implies coordination failure
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 document communication among crew and headset operator, a decision to stop pushback, and lack of warning signals, supporting a communication/coordination breakdown during the incident.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether communication failures or procedural deviations were primary cause

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during the incident

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clear and visible and the crew had adequate warning signals, or if mechanical failure caused the aircraft to move beyond the TRP, this would change the assessment.

H8 suggests communication issues but does not contradict the marking deficiency claim, favoring the environmental deficiency side in the discriminator.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement about the visibility or condition of the TRP markings; possible ambiguity about whether marking deficiency or communication failure was primary cause.

The absence of reported mechanical faults implies no mechanical control failure.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence excludes all alternative causes definitively; some ambiguity remains about the adequacy of visual signals and crew coordination.

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim is robust against potential counter-evidence or alternative explanations.

assumptions: The visual signals and communication methods described are standard and were applied as stated.
The trainee driver’s awareness and training on TRP and roles are accurate and complete.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and timely warnings from headset operator or wingman, or if environmental markings were inadequate or obscured, this would challenge the procedural deviation conclusion.
If mechanical control faults or equipment malfunctions were identified, this would undermine the procedural deviation attribution.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 describe the TRP marking and its location relative to the aircraft and blast fence, indicating the marking exists and is defined. H8 and H9 show that the driver was aware of the TRP but the visual signals for stopping were insufficient, supporting that the environmental marking was present and aligned with key features but the deficiency was in communication and procedural adherence, favoring environmental/marking deficiency over procedural deviation.

No evidence of communication failure implies communication was adequate.

If communication equipment was faulty or unavailable, this would challenge the claim.

node.statement: Environmental conditions allow for proper visibility of markings

outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in direct observation of marking visibility; no direct statement confirming visibility quality.

node.statement: Availability of trained personnel to perform pushback according to procedure

assumptions: The trainee and instructor are considered trained personnel as per evidence H9 and H1.
No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence supports it.
defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings were inadequate or obscured (contradicting H7), or if mechanical faults were documented, or if communication breakdown was proven to be primary cause, the conclusion would change.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4, H8, and H9 directly document trained personnel performing pushback with procedural deviations, including failure to stop at the TRP and inadequate communication signals, supporting availability of trained personnel but procedural deviation (R1) over environmental or mechanical causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in communication effectiveness and environmental marking adequacy, though evidence favors procedural deviation.

node.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible

assumptions: Presence of TRP markings implies required environmental markings are present and visible.
defeaters: If evidence showed markings were obscured or missing, or if crew reported inability to see markings, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 describes clear and visible TRP ground markings and clearance, while H8 indicates the visual signals for stopping were insufficient and no warnings were given, suggesting markings were present and visible but procedural issues caused the incident.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether visual signals and markings were adequate for operational safety despite being present

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and clearance are considered adequate and visible as per H7.
The visual stop signal method is considered part of procedural equipment availability.
No other equipment issues were reported in the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed that required pushback equipment was unavailable or malfunctioning at the time, or that environmental markings were inadequate or not visible, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the TRP location and clearance; H8 indicates the visual stop signal was insufficient and no warnings were given; H9 shows the trainee was trained and aware of the TRP, supporting that equipment availability was not the issue but procedural adherence was.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether equipment availability or procedural adherence was the primary cause

node.statement: Markings are maintained in a condition that ensures availability

assumptions: The presence of clear TRP markings as described in H7 implies markings were maintained and available.
Communication and procedural issues described in H8 and other history items are not caused by marking deficiencies.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were faded, obscured, or otherwise not maintained, or if there was direct testimony that markings were unavailable or unclear, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 shows adequate marking availability and condition, contradicting the claim. Evidence H8 indicates communication issues rather than marking deficiencies, supporting discrimination against environmental marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility or condition was a factor in the incident; no direct statement of marking condition deficiency

children_spec.statement: Relevant environmental data (weather, lighting, visibility) was unavailable or incomplete at the time of the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check availability and completeness of environmental data records for the incident time; absence or gaps would support this condition

children_spec.statement: Marking information (signage, runway/taxiway markings) was not available or not accessible to the flight crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Review documentation and cockpit recordings to verify if marking information was provided or accessible; lack thereof would confirm this condition

children_spec.statement: Communication or data systems providing environmental or marking information were inoperative or unreliable during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine system logs and maintenance records for failures or unreliability in communication or data systems at the incident time

children_spec.statement: Availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to ground crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if the latest pushback procedure documents were distributed and accessible to the ground crew before the operation

children_spec.statement: Availability of functional communication equipment between flight deck and ground crew during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify if communication devices were operational and used during the pushback process

children_spec.statement: Availability of trained personnel assigned to perform pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Confirm if personnel involved had required training and certification for pushback procedures

children_spec.statement: Availability of necessary ground support equipment for pushback execution
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect if all required ground equipment was present and operational at the time of pushback

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 as per hist_t2_interim is resistant to defeaters based on available evidence.

assumptions: No direct evidence of mechanical faults or control system failures is present
Procedural and communication factors are primary contributors to the event
defeaters: If evidence showed verified hardware faults or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure
If communication failures without hardware faults were documented
If physical marking or location evidence indicated environmental or marking deficiency

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, and H9 show human procedural and communication factors rather than mechanical failure, supporting resistance to defeaters for mechanical/control failure. H7 contradicts environmental deficiency, reinforcing mechanical failure as cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from mechanical failure due to overlapping operational factors
